YAPC::NA::2016 Call for Speakers
entries.text: The YAPC::NA::2016 call for speakers is now open! There must be something you could talk about: Perl 5, Perl 6, the transition between the two (either way!), some other programming language, or some other topic you think may be of interest to programmers.
entries.author: dan_wright
dan_wright
entries.text: YAPC::NA are looking for people to give master classes before and after this year's YAPC::NA.
entries.title: YAPC::NA::2016 Call for Master Classes
NICEPERL's lists
entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David's selection of new modules released to CPAN in January. He's decided not to continue with his "module of the month", considering it an experiment that has run its course. One worth looking at is Importer.
entries.title: What's new on CPAN - January 2015
Using lcpan to index your DarkPAN
entries.author: steven_haryanto
entries.text: Perlancar describes the lcpan tool, which you can use to manage your own CPAN mirror. There's going to be a series of daily tips on lcpan usage: here's the first.

entries.title: Test your Git wrapper against 500 versions of Git
entries.author: philippe_bruhat
entries.text: Philippe takes us through all the different versions of Git that he's tested Git::Repository against, and shares the scripts he's written to help with that.

entries.author: timm_murray
entries.text: A video of Timm's talk to Madison Perl Mongers about programming quadcopters in Perl.
entries.title: Programming Quadcopters, Part I

entries.author: alex_muntada
entries.text: Alex wondered what's the easiest way to serve up files using a Perl 5 module? Several people have chipped in so far in the comments, but I'm sure more of you won't be able to resist.
entries.title: Simplest way of serving local files over HTTP?

entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: As Chester discovers his son Danny has been sleeping with Annie and everyone awaits the kidnappers' demands for Jessica's release, the governor urges Burt to disassociate himself from his family.
entries.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: February 2nd-7th
Windows DLL Relocation and Perl
entries.author: andy_grundman
entries.text: Andy describes a bug found in the way Perl builds DLL files on Windows when compiling with GCC, and how it was fixed.

entries.title: Run Perl::Tidy to beautify the code
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Gabor shows how you can use Perl::Tidy to ensure your code always followings your layout preferences, even if some of it was written by someone else.

entries.title: Use Path::Tiny instead of home-made ReadFile and WriteFile
entries.text: When refactoring tests for a module, Gabor noticed functions for reading and writing files. He shows how you can use Path::Tiny for this, and also mentions File::Slurper, which is my go-to module for those tasks these days.
entries.author: gabor_szabo

entries.title: Perl-HowTo.de moved to GitHub Pages
entries.author: thomas_fahle
entries.text: I can't really tell you much beyond the title, because it's written in German.

entries.author: ricardo_signes
entries.text: When you look at a module or dist on MetaCPAN or search.cpan.org, they both show the last person who released it. Rik points out that this isn't always the most appropriate person to show, and suggests that the owner of the distribution should be displayed. He also opened a github issue for MetaCPAN, specifically about highlighting when a module has ADOPTME, HANDOFF, or NEEDHELP.
entries.title: the "credit the last uploader" problem
It takes a community to raise a CPAN module
entries.text: This was my response to Rik's post. I think that rather than show just one person, we should show everyone who's done a release, in the order of whose released most recently.
entries.author: neil_bowers

entries.title: Credit the first or last uploader on meta::cpan?
entries.author: helmut_wollmersdorfer
entries.text: This was Helmut's response to Rik's post. He thinks that everyone with upload permissions should be displayed, which is slightly different from my proposal.

entries.title: A few words on Perl 6 versioning and compatibility
entries.text: Jonathan outlines his Perl 6 will be versioned, including the language definition, the Rakudo compiler, and MoarVM.
entries.author: jonathan_worthington
jeff_goff
entries.text: Jeff continues his series on Perl 6 regular expressions and grammars, which has so far been about the former.
entries.title: From Regular Expressions to Grammars: Pt. 2

entries.text: Enkidu bemoans the fact that lots of Perl 6 modules are being created with top-level names, such as Chess, and not being put in appropriate namespaces, such as Games::Chess.
entries.author: enkidu
entries.title: Perl6 module namespace

entries.text: A MacOSX installer for the latest Perl 6 Rakudo star release is now available.
entries.title: Announce: Mac OS X Installer for release 2016.01
Text, Grammar, Tree - the 3
entries.text: Yary had been thinking about writing a reversible grammar, so you could feed it a parse tree and it would generate the original text (that had produced the parse tree). Raiph pointed out in the comments that Jonathan Worthington has a proof of concept already.

entries.title: Grant Proposal: RPerl User Documentation, Part 2
entries.text: Will Braswell has applied for a second grant: $1600 to continue work on the Learning RPerl user tutorial. Add your comments if you agree or disagree with this proposal being funded.
entries.author: makoto_nozaki

entries.title: How To Grow a Development Team ... Hotel California Style!
entries.author: andrew_solomon
entries.text: Andrew shares his tips for minimising churn while growing a development team.

entries.title: Kill Your Dependencies
entries.text: Mike Perham urges Ruby developers to look to their dependencies, and trim them down to only those really needed. As he notes, this is an issue for all programming languages.
Paul Seal's tips on being a better programmer. What would you add to his list?
entries.title: 10 golden rules for becoming a better programmer

entries.text: Michael Glukhovsky, co-founder of RethinkDB, shares his tips for how to make your project successful on GitHub. In his words, "it's all about engaging the community".
entries.title: 5 keys to project success on GitHub

header:
The Perl QA Hackathon brings together the lead developers for the Perl toolchain.
It's going to be in the UK this year. It's funded through sponsorship, so why not
see if your employer can support it. Every little helps!

How do you think authors and related users should be acknowledged when looking
at modules on MetaCPAN? This topic generated a fair bit of discussion this week.
